I'm worried I might lose my job if I can't get this under control.

I never thought my desire to provide for my family would lead me to this dark place. What started as a fun family tradition of buying weekly lottery tickets has turned into an obsession that's threatening our financial stability and my professional integrity. I find myself stopping at every convenience store on my way to and from the hospital, spending money we can't afford on the slim chance of a life-changing win. Last month, I did the unthinkable and dipped into our children's college fund to buy more tickets, convincing myself it was an investment in their future. The red numbers on the lottery tickets seem to taunt me, promising a better life just one draw away. I'm terrified of my husband discovering the extent of my addiction, of losing the trust of my patients' parents, and of failing my own children. But I can't seem to stop, always believing the next ticket will be the one. How did I, a doctor dedicated to children's health, become so blind to the harm I'm causing my own family?

I never thought my love for sports and data would lead me down this destructive path. What started as a way to add excitement to game nights has turned into an all-consuming addiction. I find myself constantly checking scores and stats, placing bets during work hours, and even neglecting my social media clients. Last month, I hit a new low when I lied to my best friend about needing money for a medical emergency, only to use it for a series of high-stakes bets. The red notification badges on my betting apps are like a constant siren call. I'm terrified of losing my job due to poor performance, of my friends discovering my lies, and of the mounting debt I'm accumulating. But I can't seem to stop, always convinced that my next bet, backed by my 'expert' analysis, will be the big win that turns everything around. How did I go from managing social media trends to being trapped by gambling trends?
